title: Investigating the Effect of Expansion on Galaxy Distances

previous.title: Exploring Rubin Observatory Data: Redness vs. Distance

content: This is a plot of brightness vs. distance of galaxies from every direction that can be observed by the Rubin Observatory. Notice in this plot that in the plot there are galaxies at distances much greater than 13.8 billion light years away. But the Universe is only 13.8 billion years old. Let’s think about how this can happen.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: If it took 13 billion years for the light from a distant galaxy to travel to Earth, and the Universe wasn’t expanding, how far away would this galaxy be from Earth?
